p.s: In the following John Worne's newspaper article will be analysed concerning his use of language and communicative strategies.

He begins with underlingunderlining the British mentality towards foreign language learning by using the words can't, won't, don't to conclude the national view in both the nonne of his article and in line one.
He thereby also creates the comparison to a small, grizzling Babybaby, refusing to eat it'sits vegetables even though they're good for him.
This immediately gives the reader the feeling of not wanting to be seen as one of these can't, won't, don't-people.

One of his most convincing writing traits is his constant reference to studies and numbers which perfectly back up what he is saying, mostly about the declinigdeclining interest in yougyoung people to learn foreign languages (cf. ll. 3-5, cf. ll. 10-12, cf. ll. 13-16, cf. ll. 28-30).

This gives the reader the impression of a super educated, very factual article, even though the author isn't all that, as he manages to also add his own bias to the studies, for example by using the word sadly (l. 5) to describe the results of a study.
This gives the reader an instant negative judgement of these numbers without letting him/ her form their own conlusionconclusion from a study.

Another part of his article where the author's views on the matter come through heavily are the lines 18-23, in which he debunks people disagreeing with his opinion by using ironic remarks, which oneon the one hand make the author seem more down to earth to the reader but also have a comedic aspect in them which gives the reader the impression of not having to take counter argumentscounterarguments seriously.
This is further supported by a very sly description of the critics: Perfectly intelligent people (l. 18).
This is a hidden way of saying those people are usually smart, but astoundingly dim concerning the discussed subject, which once again takes credibility from those people.
A further communicative strategy the author makes use of is displayed in the lines 24-27.
Here the author states his own opinion but doesn't mark it as such by using terms like "I feel", "I think" or "I believe", thus desguisingdisguising a personal view as a fact to the reader.
Worne also chooses his pronouns very carefully: He makes multiple use of inclusive and exclusive language.

On the one hand he makes the reader feel closer to him and makes clear that this is a problem they must fight hand in hand, for example in line 6-7: of us recommissioning our collective brains, in which he also underlines the inclusion by using the word collective, but also in line 48: we as parents and in line 50: our children's, with one "super-inclusion" in line 46, in which he on the other hand first of all excludes the reader as parents for his appeal to be recognized as one, but then continues to make sure he himself also has to tackle on this problem and that it's a duty they must face together.
(This also implies he is already doing it correctly).

Another way of praising the advocates of his opinion and bashing the people who don't give foreign language learning as much importance as Worne feels it deserves is him writing forward thinking universities (line 36-37).
This implies to the reader that any universities who don't have similar programs as the ones he supports are "backward-thinking".
Another way in which the author underlines the immediate vedescity for action is the combination of the overstatement / hyperbole There is no doubt and the personification the UK needs in line 42.
This gives the reader the idea of a United Kingdom which can't "live on" in the future without yougyoung people having developed their foreign language skills.
Finally, in his Appealappeal, John Worne makes use of yet another metaphor: as essential strings to our children's bows (line 50).

He hereby paints a picture of Parentsparents catapulting their children into a better future by sorting them out with international and language-related experiences (cf. l. 49) and also a of completing the children's tool set and making their feats strong enough for them to get a good job and life when they grow up.

All in all John Worne uses many examples and studies to first of all back up his point that the interest in foreign language learning is decreasing and then follows up by convincing the reader of the importance of learning languages next to English, using many stylistic devices auch as irony and inclusive language.
